nodes.bodyText:
I've use auto-generated passwords in public charts that I maintain before. I wouldn't recommend it as on upgrades it will auto-generate with a new secret that won't work if the application is stateful and only creates users once (like databases).
Also, this value is used in two places in the secret: deep in the application.yaml config and separately as metricsPassword. I'm not sure how to generate it and merge it back into the config yaml. I think hardcoded is fine and we'll just add documentation later listing all the passwords properties that should be changed (there's quite a bit and some outside our control).

nodes.bodyText:
One method for doing that would be to hash the secret and use it as an annotation on whatever relies on application.yml (the REST API I'm guessing?).
https://sanderknape.com/2019/03/kubernetes-helm-configmaps-changes-deployments/
Any change to the secret would cause a rolling update to any resources which referenced it. As long as they aren't stateful (like the DB example you pointed out) it should work.
It may make sense to do all this sort of secret management in a single pass though, if there are other places that could use love too.
